p: The primary sources of prestige for learning patterns are knowledge, age, and gender, particularly older and more successful people [ 13, 15]. If prestige for any of these variables drives social learning, we expect to find patterns of popularity (the number of people who say they learned from a given person) in our observed network (Hypotheses 3a-c, Table 1). In the cultural context of Solomon Islands, men and women have distinct gender roles and restrictions, and men tend to have more political power and ancestral knowledge than women, so men will tend to have more prestige [ 46, 51].
